14:30 <dan18> hello  
14:30 <dan18> i am completely new to xwiki, but have some experience with wiki in general  
14:31 <@cjdelisle> Any specific questions I can help answer?  
14:31 <dan18> is there a way to install and name macros, those that i find in the extension list, and the "call" them  
14:31 <dan18> with a simple tagged expression  
14:32 <dan18> or do i need to repeatedely copy and paste all macro code inline?  
14:32 <@cjdelisle> Are you talking about velocity script macros or xwiki macros?  
14:32 <dan18> hi cjdelisle  
14:33 <dan18> not sure really, don't yet know the distinctions, i guess i refer to code i find when searching the xwiki extensions  
14:33 <dan18> probably velocity  
14:33 <@cjdelisle> In velocity, you can define script macros with the #macro() directive. These will allow you to make macro calls in velocity script.  
14:34 <dan18> how does one usually include velocity scripts one finds into the wiki  
14:34 <@cjdelisle> For XWiki macros, you can create a document containing an XWikiMacro object, then anywhere in the wiki you can call {{yourMacro param1=value1 param2=value2 /}}  
14:34 <@cjdelisle> I think XWiki macros are the ones you are thinking of if you have a MediaWiki background.  
14:35 <dan18> lets take an example, to clarify  
14:35 <mflorea> has joined #xwiki  
14:35 <dan18> i happen to look at a Livetable Generator extension  
14:35 <dan18> in another window  
14:36 <dan18> its quite elaborate code, probably velocity code  
14:36 <dan18> as an admin, would i copy and paste this into some page or even space, set aside for macros  
14:37 <@cjdelisle> if it's called with #yourMacro() then its velocity  
14:38 <@cjdelisle> If you're trying to write complex script then you want velocity macros, if you want to make it easy for users to add foratted content like in MediaWiki, you want XWikiMacros  
14:38 <dan18> its not documented ,what the call convention is: http://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Livetable+Generator#HDescription  
14:38 <dan18> ok  
14:38 <dan18> right now i only want to use macros, preferrably those that help to format contents, but also collect some information such as child pages  
14:38 <dan18> (if those exist)  
14:39 <@cjdelisle> Velocity macros only work inside of velocity scripts though  
14:40 <dan18> i guess i really need to learn the vocabulary first  
14:40 <@cjdelisle> So if you want to display something, it's easiest to develop an XWiki macro, then you can use {{myMacro param=val/}}  
14:40 <dan18> probably am not using it correctly  
14:41 <@cjdelisle> If you are using velocity macros, then you need to put them in a velocity script like this:  
14:41 <@cjdelisle> {{velocity}}#myMacro(param, param, param){{/velocity}}  
14:41 <@cjdelisle> ^note that the {{velocity}} is itself an xwiki macro invocation.  
14:42 <dan18> i guess as a newcomer i am first interested in undestanding how to make use of extensions included in the xwiki extensions "directory"  
14:42 <dan18> when you browser those extensions that you notice that some are, what you called xwiki macros, while others elaborate velocity code  
14:43 <@cjdelisle> Each one is different, they are contributed by users who just needed a certain feature and write it.  
14:43 <@cjdelisle> \*wrote it  
14:43 <dan18> right, so as a user/admin, my first task would be to know how to make use of them  
14:43 <dan18> how are they "imported" into a xwiki  
14:43 <@cjdelisle> I think the best thing to do is read a few of them just to get a handle on how scripting works.  
14:44 <@cjdelisle> If they are "snippets" then you can just paste them into a wiki page, applications can be imported using the import function.  
14:44 <dan18> i will surely do that, but as a first step, i only want to know how to use them as a black box  
14:45 <dan18> right. i think anything that is more than 2-3 lines of code would probably be best imported  
14:45 <dan18> otherwise there is a lot of repetition  
14:45 <@cjdelisle> Keep in mind that since some of them are old and the API does change, they may not all work without modifications, some may not work at all anymore (I think we weeded most of those out though)  
14:45 <dan18> where is the import function located/accessed  
14:46 <dan18> ok, thats good to know.  
14:46 <@cjdelisle> Oh, you can paste it into one page then include that page where you want to use it.  
14:46 <dan18> how does one include a page  
14:46 <@cjdelisle> We have a built in {{include}} macro.  
14:47 <dan18> something like {{include page=pagename}}  ?  
14:47 <@cjdelisle> http://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Include+Macro  
14:47 <dan18> jup thats gret  
14:47 <dan18> great  
14:47 <dan18> how do you import macros?  
14:47 <dan18> or rather scripts  
14:48 <@cjdelisle> If you have an application (this is a .xar file) you import it through the administrtion interface, as admin, upper left dropdown menu, "Administor Wiki"  
14:48 <dan18> .xar sounds like compiled code, or is it just plain script text  
14:49 <@cjdelisle> It's the export/import format. It's zipped xml files, you can look inside of one by unzipping it.  
14:50 <dan18> perhaps i can ask you another question  
14:51 <dan18> how can i create a hierarchy of pages  
14:51 <dan18> within a space  
14:51 <dan18> can this be done?  
14:51 <@cjdelisle> Each page has a "parent" field.  
14:52 <@cjdelisle> This is pertty flexable, the parent of a page can actually be in a different space.  
14:52 <DrLou> has joined #xwiki  
14:52 <dan18> ok, say, i just created a new page in a space  
14:52 <dan18> or rather a new space with a top level page called scripts  
14:53 <dan18> what do i do to create a child page called livetable  
14:53 <dan18> so that the child is in the same space  
14:54 <dan18> i can see the add page menu item, but i think it adds a page "globally" and not as a child of the current viewed page  
14:56 <@cjdelisle> When you're editing a page, there's a little icon right above where it says "Title:" (upper left, just above where you type)  
14:56 <@cjdelisle> it allows you to edit the parent of that page
